revision.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]|expiry=08:36, 11 March 2019|small=yes}} {{Unreferenced|date=August 2009}} {{Globalize |date=June 2016}}
[[The Tote]] is a [[bookmaker]] in Britain which offers [[parimutuel betting]] on British horse racing in Britain. Until July 2018 the Tote was the only bookmaker in Britain allowed to offer parimutuel betting on horse racing, although as of July 13th 2018 the existing monopoly protection the Tote ceased, and a number of other tote or parimutuel suppliers entered the British market. Other bookmakers offer a Tote service through syndication, while other bookmakers will accept a Tote bet and pay out on exactly the same terms as the Tote.
The pooled bets offered by The UK Tote are:
Win, Place, Exacta, Trifecta, Quadpot, Placepot, Jackpot, Scoop6 and Swinger.
== Terminology == As other bookmakers can offer similar gambling services it is necessary to disambiguate the bets. A bookmaker win-only bet (on-the-nose) isn't the same as a Tote Win bet, as the bookmaker is offering fixed odds for that particular outcome, while the Tote is a dividend paid out from the [[betting pool]]. The betting pool is generated from individuals placing money on a Tote bet.
A price quote for a horse on the Tote is the current dividend payout on the event of that outcome happening. This tends to be similar to normal bookmaker odds, and tracks the market in a similar way, but at any given time may be better or worse than a bookmaker's quoted odds. However, since all bets are pooled, all bets are essentially "starting price" (SP), that is, until the race has started (and all betting finished) one cannot calculate what the final payout will be; whereas bookmakers can offer either SP or a "board price", that is, a guaranteed payout at a given price for a winning bet. (The SP for horse races is the average price offered by bookmakers when the race starts, as inspected by employees of the [[Jockey Club]]).
It is sometimes suggested that Tote odds are generally less favourable than bookmakers' SPs. This claim is controversial, some assert they vary little from bookmakers' odds.
== Tote Win ==
The minimum stake for this bet is £2. One selects a horse from the field. This can be on any horse at any race meeting. The betting slip can be denoted with the horse's race card number, or the horses name (and if at another course, the name of the course), or it can be marked as the 'favourite', where the horse is not nominated but the bet is placed on whichever horse is favourite (has the largest amount of money put into the pool) at the start of the race. This will, obviously, have the lowest payout (since the pool will be shared with the largest number of winners) but the assumption is that if others have bet on it, it must have a good chance of winning.
== Tote Place ==
A Tote Place bet is still on one, but the horse may come second, third or even fourth for the bet to win. Not every race qualifies for this type of bet. There must be a minimum of 5 horses in the field, the minimum stake is £2 and the following rules apply:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Number of runners ! Dividend places |- | Up to 4 runners | Unavailable |- | 5, 6 or 7 runners | 1 - 2 |- | 8 - 15 runners in handicaps 8+ runners in non-handicaps | 1 - 2 - 3 |- | 16+ runners handicaps | 1 - 2 - 3 - 4 |}
== Each-Way ==
It is also possible to have an each-way ("e/w") bet, which is simply a combination of a Tote Win with a Tote Place bet. A £1 e/w bet is a total of £2, £1 for the Tote Win and the other £1 is for the Tote Place, and the money is split between the two separate pools (the Win pool and the Place pool).
Bookmakers other than the Tote do not generally offer a place-only bet, but only an each-way bet. This can be seen as a waste by bettors who believe their selection will finish 2nd or 3rd but will not come 1st; since half the money falls on the "win" it is wasted. A non-Tote bookmaker will offer a quarter or a fifth for the e/w component, whereas the Tote place payout, and as such the e/w payout, is as always the betting pool dividend. With the advent of the exchanges, more and more bookmakers are beginning to offer 'place only' markets in an attempt to rival the exchanges. However, there is not a set in stone way for a punter to calculate the place odds as there is with an each-way bet, and the special place only odds offered by bookmakers can vary quite a bit, both bigger and smaller, from the place odds you would receive if betting each-way. This is particularly true in "bad each-way" races, where the place odds are much less generous than if you bet each-way. The upside to this however goes back to what was said above; since the punter does not have to "waste" half their stake on the win part of the bet.
== Tote Exacta ==
The Tote Exacta operates in the same way as a normal bookmaker's straight forecast. As always the Tote price for the forecast is always based on the betting pool dividend. A forecast is to predict the correct order of the horses finishing first and second. The minimum bet is £2 and the multiples of 10 pence over this, multiples can also be used to reach the initial minimum of £2. If the bet contains a non-runner the bet becomes void and unnamed favourites are not allowed.
There are three Exacta bets:
Single Exacta (straight forecast). Pick in the correct order the horses which will finish first and second.
Combination Exacta (reverse forecast). Pick in either order the horses which will finish first and second. This bet is actually two bets in one, it is exactly equivalent to two straight forecasts, the first of which you select horse A to beat horse B, and then the second is for horse B to beat horse A. It's possible to specify more than two horses, at which point the bet becomes more complex, for example with three horses the individual bets are now a-b, a-c, b-a, b-c, c-a, c-b.
Banker Exacta (banker forecast). Pick a horse which you think is going to finish first, and then any number of horses to finish second. For instances, with a banker horse a, and with three additional horses, the bets are a-b, a-c, a-d.
Bookmakers that are not Tote-syndicated will offer their own forecast prices based on their own odds that they are quoting. However bookmakers will normally allow you to place a 'Tote forecast' and will pay out whatever the Tote dividend payout was.
== Tote Trifecta ==
Also known as a Trifecta: pick the first three horses in the right order. This is generally really difficult to do and the dividend for getting it right is correspondingly better. The Tote can nominate races containing more than 8 runners as Trifecta races. There are three types of Trifecta, the Single, Combination and Banker and they work the same way as Exacta bets, only with three horses instead of two. The minimum stake is £2.
== Tote Quadpot ==
A Quadpot is operated on one race at every meeting in the UK and it takes place on the third to sixth races on the card. The aim is to pick a horse that will be placed in each one of these races, according to the placing rules stated in the Tote Place section above. The minimum bet is 10p. The dividend is declared after the result of the last race is known and thus the betting pool divided by the remaining stakes which are left. One may select the favourite instead of naming a specific horse.
== Tote Placepot ==
The Placepot is identical to the Quadpot except it operates over the first six races of a race card. All UK race meetings have six races as a minimum, occasionally seven and rarely eight, but the Placepot is always operated on the first six. This bet is very popular as it has the potential to allow a gambler involvement in the whole of the race card. The minimum bet is 5p. Here is a worked example:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Race ! Selection 1 ! Selection 2 ! Selection 3 ! Selection 4 |- | One | 2 | 7 | | |- | Two | F | | | |- | Three | F | 11 | | |- | Four | 4 | | | |- | Five | 6 | | | |- | Six | F | 1 | 3 |}
The first race the gambler has opted to choose two horses. Maybe the gambler isn't confident of his abilities or maybe it is a large field and the gambler feels unable to just place one horse. On race two the gambler has elected to roll with the favourite, whatever it may be. In the final race the gambler has chosen three selections. This is often driven by the motive that if the gambler reaches the last race and still has a bet on, he doesn't want to lose out in the last race by only having one selection. The number of combinations in this bet is therefore 2 × 1 × 2 × 1 × 1 × 3 = 12. The gambler has decided to risk 20p per bet, so the total cost of this bet is £2.40.
If after the first race the gambler has failed to pick a selection which was placed then the bet is over. If a selection is placed, then the bet continues, and the winnings are transferred as the stake on the second race. In this example, horse 2 may be placed and horse 7 unplaced, which means the bet continues – but there are now only 6 valid combinations for winning left.
If the gambler is lucky and managed to get through to the end, then the Tote will calculate the dividend for a £1 unit stake. In this example the Tote is going to declare the dividend as £30, and the lucky gambler has 2 winning combinations. Two combinations at a stake level of 20p is 40p, so 40% of £30 is £12, a profit of £9.60.
If a favourite is placed in every single race the Placepot payout is typically as low as it can get, and it could be anywhere from £3 to £15, although anything less than £6–£7 is quite unusual. If favourites fail to finish in the places for half of the races then something around the £40–£200 could be anticipated, placepots of over £25,000 have been known but they are extremely uncommon. However, there isn't a science to guessing what the placepot might be, the placepot dividend is the calculation of the number of tickets left divided by the pool money.
There are a couple of additional rules which affect the operation of the Placepot (and indeed the Quadpot/Jackpot/Scoop6). If a selection becomes a non-runner it will be replaced by the Starting Price favourite. Where there are joint favourites and the gambler has selected to roll on the Favourite, then the horse with the lowest race card number will be taken. If the favourite withdraws (for instance, the horse refuses to enter its starting gate) and the market has no time to select a new favourite the horse with the next shortest odds will become the favourite. It's rare for a race card to progress without a couple of non-runners so a gambler will be affected by these rules from time to time.
== Tote Jackpot ==
The Tote Jackpot is a bet where you have to pick the first 6 winners at a meeting nominated by The Tote. The bet is available every day of the week. The minimum stake is £1 and multiples are in multiples of 50p. Typically the payouts are very good for the Jackpot as it is very difficult to pick six winners in a row. The betting pool will roll into the next Jackpot event if there is no dividend to pay.
== Tote Scoop6 ==
Similar to the Tote Jackpot, Tote Scoop6 is run on Saturdays and occasionally on other days such as Boxing Day, and has been branded this way for television audiences, generally Scoop6 races are shown on [[terrestrial television]] in the UK. The stake for one line is £2, as opposed to a minimum 50p in the case of the Jackpot. As the pool will roll-over in the event of there being no dividends to pay the pool can become very large and wins in excess of £500,000 have been known. There is also a bonus fund whereby the winner of a Scoop6 event can attempt to pick the winner of the most difficult race in next week's Scoop6. This bet is also a Placepot bet, as the Tote also payout a dividend for selecting a horse to be placed in each race. According to the Tote, the average dividend is over £500 for a winning place line.
There is a major operational difference to this bet as compared to the Jackpot/Placepot/Quadpot: the six races on the Scoop6 card are nominated by the Tote from any of the race meetings on that day, typically the Scoop6 card will have a number of very difficult races such as handicap races with over 20 horses running, and races with 2- or 3-year-olds where many horses have no track record, making it difficult to select a winner. It is also the reason why the placepot payouts are correspondingly higher than a normal placepot as well. The televised coverage usually announces how many Scoop6 tickets are left after each Scoop6 race, and it is quite common to be left with only three or four tickets after the first four races.
As with other Tote bets, non-syndicated bookmakers will normally accept a Tote bet and pay out in line with the Tote dividend.
== Toteswinger ==
This is a single-race exotic bet available on all races of six or more runners at every meeting, every day, players have to pick two horses to finish 1st, 2nd or 3rd in any order.
Each bet offers three chances to win as follows: * Picking the horses that finish first and second in any order * Picking the horses that finish first and third in any order * Picking the horses that finish second and third in any order
A different dividend is declared for each outcome.
The minimum unit stake for a toteswinger bet is 10p (shops and online). Minimum unit stake on-course is 50p with minimum total spend £2 as per all totepool on-course bets. Toteswinger is unique to the tote; there is no other equivalent fixed odds or SP bet.
This is an extremely popular bet in overseas racing markets, particularly South Africa where it accounts for 40% of pool turnover.
==External links== * [http://www.racingpost.co.uk/c4/blank.sd?page=The%20Tote An introduction to Tote betting]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tote Betting}} [[Category:Wagering]] [[Category:Gambling terminology]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
The '''Turnip Prize''' is a spoof UK award satirising the [[Tate Gallery]]'s [[Turner Prize]] by rewarding deliberately bad modern art. It was started as a joke in 1999, but gained national media attention and inspired similar prizes. Credit is given for entries containing bad puns as titles, displaying "lack of effort" or "is it shit?". Conversely, entries with "too much effort" or "not shit enough" are immediately disqualified. The first prize is a [[turnip]] nailed to a block of wood.
==History== The prize (now awarded in the New Inn) was conceived in 1999 by management and regulars of The George Hotel, [[Wedmore]], [[Somerset]], after the exhibition of [[Tracey Emin]]'s ''[[My Bed]]'' was shortlisted for the [[Turner Prize]]. It is organised by Trevor Prideaux and was announced thus: "The Turnip Prize is a crap art competition ... You can enter anything you like, but it must be rubbish." The competition is based on the supposition, "We know it's rubbish, but is it art?". Competitors submitted entries of ridiculous objects posing as contemporary art, mostly made from junk titled with spoofs or puns. The prize is a turnip impaled on a rusty six-inch nail.
In May 2000, the nominees appeared on the [[BBC]] TV ''[[Esther (TV series)|Esther]]'' show, presented by [[Esther Rantzen]] and featured by national and international media.
In 2001, the competition was held in the public conveniences in Wedmore.
In 2002, the "Monster Raving Loony Party" attempted to hijack the competition at The Trotter, Crickham, Wedmore.
In 2003, the winner was James Timms with ''Take a Leaf out of My Chook'', an exhibit of a raw chicken stuffed with leaves.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/somerset/3253406.stm |title=Chicken sculpture scoops 'Turnip Prize |publisher=BBC News |date=1 December 2003 |accessdate=8 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Ananova |url=http://dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_5-12-2003_pg9_2 |title=Unicyclist wins Turnip Prize for rubbish art |newspaper=Daily Times (Pakistan) |date=5 December 2003 |accessdate=9 January 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930182833/http://dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_5-12-2003_pg9_2 |archive-date=2007-09-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> James Timms subsequently appeared on BBC Radio Scotland's ''[[Fred MacAulay]] Show'' with [[Ed Byrne (comedian)|Ed Byrne]].{{cn|date=November 2018}}
In 2005, Ian Osenthroat, a 69-year-old former photocopier salesman, won with the exhibit ''Birds Flew'', a bird's nest with a flu remedy box. He commented satirically, "I have entered this most coveted art award on several occasions and I really feel that the lack of effort this year has really paid off."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/somerset/4502954.stm |title=Bird's nest awarded Turnip Prize |publisher=BBC News |date=6 December 2005 |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
Winner in 2006 was Ian Lewis with the exhibit ''Torn Beef'', an empty [[corned beef]] can. He stated, "The work took no time at all to create." Trevor Prideaux commented, "I believe that over the last seven years the bad artists of Wedmore and surrounding areas have created far better works than [[Nicholas Serota]] and The [[Tate Britain]] Gallery could ever wish to exhibit."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thewestonmercury.co.uk/content/twm/news/story.aspx?brand=Westonmercury&category=news&tBrand=westonmercury&tCategory=znews&itemid=WeED11%20Dec%202006%2010%3A54%3A04%3A960 |title=And this year's prize turnip is ... Ian Lewis! |newspaper=Weston & Somerset Mercury |date=11 December 2006 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927140441/http://www.thewestonmercury.co.uk/content/twm/news/story.aspx?brand=Westonmercury&category=news&tBrand=westonmercury&tCategory=znews&itemid=WeED11%20Dec%202006%2010:54:04:960}}</ref> Also in 2006, the [[BBC]]'s Chief Somerset Correspondent, [[Clinton Rogers]], was immortalised as ''Clint on a Row of Jars''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/somerset/content/image_galleries/turnip_prize_2006_gallery.shtml |title=Turnip Prize 2006 |publisher=BBC Somerset |date=1 December 2006 |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
In 2007, the competition gained more publicity with the entry of artwork with the title ''By the Banksea''. The painting bears a striking resemblance to work by the famous Bristol graffiti artist [[Banksy]], and its origins are likewise a closely guarded secret. ''By the Banksea'' portrays a seaside [[Aunt Sally]] in the form of a stencil of the ''[[Mona Lisa]]'', but in true Banksy style, Mona Lisa is depicted holding a rocket launcher firing a turnip over the wreckage of a seaside pier and an emergency exit sign. Competition organiser Trevor Prideaux commented: "It does seem to be in Banksy's style. But someone has thought too much about this one and tried too hard. So for that reason it's not likely to win." The piece was duly disqualified for "too much effort, and not shit enough." The 2007 competition was won by Bracey Vermin with ''Tea P'', a group of used tea bags in the shape of a letter P.
Competition entries for 2010 included "Ivor Crush"{{'}}s clothes hanger linking the letter U in "Crush", entitled ''Hung up on You'', and an entry by Banksy, which focused on the recent student protests of the day.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-11847516 |title=Turnip Prize entries compete for top bad art accolade |publisher=BBC News Somerset |date=26 November 2010 |accessdate=30 November 2010}}</ref>
Entries for 2011 included a piece of cheese carved into the letter E, entitled ''CheeseE'', ''A fish full of dollars'', and an exhibit of an Action Man toy – called ''First Class Mail'' – with a carefully placed stamp, and a coloured rock called ''Half a Stone Lighter''. This year's prize featured on the BBC's ''[[Have I Got News For You]]'' for two weeks running.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-15902670 |title=Turnip Prize bad art contest finalists are revealed |publisher=BBC News Somerset |date=26 November 2011 |accessdate=27 November 2011}}</ref>
'''2012''' – 87 entries.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/weird-news/the-three-tenas-wins-the-turnip-prize-1470478 |title=Taking the pee: 'The Three Tenas' crap art prize winner really is pants |newspaper=Daily Mirror |first=Roland |last=Ellison |date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
'''2013''' – 69 entries, which included entries from Ireland, Italy, Paris, and the USA.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-25184055 |title=Turnip Prize: See the winner and finalists in Somerset's bad art contest |publisher=BBC News Somerset |date=2 December 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
'''2014''' – 69 entries, which included entries from Canada, USA, Germany, and Italy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-30274103 |title=Turnip Prize: Ewe Kip wins Somerset bad art contest |publisher=BBC News |date=1 December 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
'''2015''' – 69 entries, which included entries from France, Czech Republic, Norway and Macedonia.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-35010750 |title=The Turnip Prize: 'Dismal And' wins spoof art accolade |date=7 December 2015 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
'''2016''' – 99 entries, which included entries from Brisbane, Australia (delivered by hand), Scotland, Northern Ireland, and Lundy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thewestonmercury.co.uk/news/poldark-announced-as-winner-of-coveted-turnip-prize-1-4811160|title=Poldark announced as winner of coveted Turnip Prize|newspaper=Weston Mercury |date=11 December 2016 |access-date=6 December 2017|language=en}}</ref>
'''2017''' – 100 entries, which included entries from Guernsey and Germany.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spoof art triumphs once again at the 2017 Turnip Prize|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-somerset-42244179| publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 December 2017|date=5 December 2017}}</ref>
==Winners and shortlisted artists== ''This list is nearly complete''
* 1999 – '''David Stone''' (baker), winner – ''[[Alfred the Great|Alfred The Grate]]'' (two burned rolls on a fire grate) **David Gannon (British Airways worker) – ''Sharp Infested Waters'' (a jar of water filled with needles, razors and knives) **Neil Ellis – ''Soiled Serviette'' (a comment on a crumpled piece of paper) **Iain Jones – ''Half Cut'' (a saw and a piece of wood cut halfway through with a bottle of beer nearby) **Maureen Hodge (pub landlady) – ''Laundry Day Tracey'' (a neat pile of clean sheets) * 2000 – '''Jacqui Redman''' (care worker, age 30), winner – ''Minstrel Cycle'' (a bicycle constructed of sweets, cocktail sticks and tampons) **Jenny Vining (midwife, age 21+) – ''[[Serial killer|Cereal Killer]]'' (cereal packets with bullet holes in them) **Kerry Bobbett (trainee graphic designer, age 19) – ''[[The Wind in the Willows|Wind In The Willows]]'' (a tin of beans in a wicker basket) **Sue Smith (age 50+) – ''[[World Wide Web|Surf In The Net]]'' (a box of washing powder in a net) * 2001 – '''Chloe Wilson''', winner – ''nothing'' (which was literally nothing) * 2002 – '''Jenny Vining '''(midwife), winner – ''Piston Broke'' (a broken piston mounted onto a block of wood) **Dick Stelling (landlord, age 69) – ''A Bit on the Side'' (a horse's bit on its side) **James Timms (trapeze artist) – ''Privot Investigator'' (a [[privet]] bush and magnifying glass) * 2003 – '''James Timms''' (long-distance unicyclist, age 26), winner – ''Take a Leaf out of my Chook'' (a raw chicken stuffed with leaves) **Di Vorce – ''Bitter and Twisted'' (a piece of grapefruit peel) **Jonny Wilkinson – ''[[Jonny Wilkinson]]'' (a condom and a razor blade) **Polly Ethylene – ''What a Waste'' (a sculpture of plumbing pipes) * 2004 – '''Pearl E Queen''' (former chimney sweep, age **Claire Prior – ''Half a Stone Lighter'' **Ian Lewis – ''Light Lunch'' (a sculpture using china, paper, steel and glass) *2005 – '''Ian Osenthroat''' (former photocopier salesman, age 69), winner – ''[[Avian influenza|Birds Flew]]'' (an empty birds' nest with a flu remedy) **Ian Lewis – ''Political Promises'' (an empty jar) **The Mysterious Baker – ''Half Baked'' (baked bread in the shape of ½) **Robert Baby – ''Leakin' Wellington'' (a leek protruding from a wellington boot) **The Sisters Incognito – ''The Hand of Time'' (a papier-mâché sculpture of a clock face) *2006 – '''Ian Lewis''' (Iron Man), winner – ''Torn Beef'' (an empty corned beef can) **''[[Home! Sweet Home!|Ham Sweet Ham]]'' (disqualified) (a framed picture containing two slices of ham and a boiled sweet) **''Beyond [[The Pale|the Pale]]'' **''Captain's Log'' **[[Clinton Rogers]] (BBC's Chief Somerset Correspondent) – ''Clint on a Row of Jars'' **''Cracked Pot'' (a broken plant pot) **''Medium Steak'' (a medium-sized wooden stake) **''The [[Second Coming]]'' *2007 – '''Bracey Vermin''' (jam maker), winner – ''[[Tipi|Tea P]]'' (used tea bags in the shape of a P) **Mary Leftley, very highly commended – ''[[Tempus fugit|Thyme Flies]]'' (dead flies in a hexagonal jar with [[thyme]]) **Mr Fezzy Wig, very highly commended – ''[[Paradise Lost|Pair o' dice Lost]]'' (a map of Scotland with dice) **John Squires, very highly commended – ''[[Mincemeat|Mints Meet]]'' (a mincemeat jar containing a [[polo mint]] and an [[Extra Strong Mints|extra strong mint]]) **Isaac Hasumoff – ''[[Flying saucer|Fly in Saucer]]'' (a saucer with a dead fly), 2007 Special Award. "Judges considered that this was an exceptional lack of effort. However, the fly cannot be considered rubbish (it is not recyclable unless ingested by a spider)." *2008 – '''Ivor Pranced''' (farmer), winner – ''Fleeced'' (a piece of sheep's wool depicting [[John containing naked [[Barbie]] dolls) **Mary Christmas – ''[[Noddy Holder]]'' (a [[Noddy (character)|Noddy]] bucket) **Aunt Sponge – ''Shi Tart'' (a tart with the letters SHI in it) *2010 – '''Doug in the United Kingdom|Elfin Safety]]'' (a builders' hard hat with elf ears on it) **Gill Adams – ''It's [[Margarine|Marge]]'' ([[I Can't Believe It's Not Butter!]] container with [[Marge Simpson]] in it) **Jo Hill – ''Polish Worker'' (a duster or cleaning cloth) **New Blood – ''A Leg Up'' (an old table leg stood on its end) **Sarah Quick – ''[[Brief Encounter]]'' (an abacus with a pair of pants over it) *2011 – '''Jim Drew''' (bush trimmer), winner – ''Jamming with [[Muddy Waters]]'' (a jar containing jam and some muddy water) **Granny Abuse – ''[[A Fistful of Dollars|Fish Full of Dollars]]'' (a fish stuffed full of dollars) **Mr Fezziwig – ''Half a Stone Lighter'' (a stone with one half lighter in colour than the other side) **Aunt Sponge – ''[[Children in Need|Children in Mead]]'' (a bottle of [[mead]] with lots of dolls in it) **Andy Gould – ''CheesE'' (a piece of cheese cut into an "E" shape) **Team GB – ''First Class Mail'' (an [[Action Man]] toy with a first-class Broke'' (a stone broken in two) **James Standon – ''Bread in Captivity'' (a loaf of bread in a pet-carrying cage) **Mike Atkinson – ''[[Children in Need|Children in Knead]]'' (a lump of dough with children in it) *2013 – '''Percy Long-Prong''' (former chauffeur), winner – ''Play on Words'' (a Shakespeare play on top of a dictionary) **Chris McKinley – ''Slightly Open'' (a jar) **Hugh Grant – ''Brookes Hair Hacked'' (a pile of red wood shavings) **Tony Edmunds – ''[[Flower Power]]'' (a flower and a battery) **Cobbsy – ''[[The Hobbit]]'' (a ring off the top of a cooker) **Guido Barbato – ''Smarty Pants'' (pants coming out of a [[Smarties]] tube) *2014 – '''Ms Drunken Shepherd''' (shepherdess), winner – ''[[UK Independence Party|Ewe Kip]]'' (a sleeping sheep) **Abby – ''[[Gogglebox]]'' (an empty box of goggles) **Leafy – ''Pensive'' (a pen and a sieve) **Aunt Sponge – ''Stick another Shrimp on the [[barbecue|Barbie]]'' (Barbie doll with shrimps stuck on it) **Trees R Green – ''[[Ginger snap|Ginger Nut]]'' (a walnut with ginger hair) **Mike Anderson – ''[[Breast implant|Breast in Plant]]'' (breasts embedded in a plant) *2015 – '''Bonksy''' (rocket scientist), winner – ''[[Dismaland|Dismal And]]'' (the symbol "&" looking dismal) **P.Enfold – ''[[Danger Mouse (1981 TV series)|Danger Mouse]]'' (a computer mouse with an electrical warning sticker on it) **Art Ist – ''Staple Diet'' (a galvanised staple on a plate) **Asif – ''A Clean Slate'' (a piece of slate with nothing on it) **Pat McGroin – ''Hung like a Donkey'' (a donkey hanging on a rope) **Imogen Crees – ''A Roll in the Hay'' (a bread roll in some hay) *2016 – '''Plumsky''' (sommelier) – ''[[Poldark|Pole Dark]]'' (a black pole) **Sovereign Steve – ''Bricks It'' (three red bricks arranged as the letters IT) **Hair Minge – ''[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]'' (a Barbie doll giving birth to a party blower) **E.B.Trumped – ''[[Barack Obama#Post-presidency (2017–present)|Oh Baaah Ma Leaves]]'' (two sheep and some leaves) **Willy Dropum – ''Pair of Drawers'' (a pair of drawers from a bureau) **Kick Ass O – ''The [[European Single Market|European Single Meerkat]]'' (a lone [[meerkat]] holding a European flag) *2017 – '''Chris P Bacon''' (Year 8 student) – ''[[Pulled pork|Pulled Pork]]'' (a tractor pulling a pig) **Sue D'onim – ''[[Fake news|Fake Nudes]]'' (Barbie and [[Ken (doll)|Ken]] naked and holding hands) **Tiger Would – ''[[Minnie Driver]]'' (a small golf club) **Keepthefaith – ''[[Northern soul|Northern Soul]]'' (a shoe with a compass on its sole) **Lady (Sheila) Critters – ''[[Ant & Dec|Pant & Dec]]'' (a pair of pants with playing cards on top) **N Eedl Ife – ''[[Pornhub]]'' (internet hub with a [[Pawn (chess)|chess pawn]] on top)
==Other competitions==
Many independent "Turnip Prize" competitions are now held around the world, with differing rules made up by those who are running the competitions. Competitions generally aspire to concept, "We know it's rubbish, but is it art?" and competitors submit entries made from junk with titles that are nonsensical or puns. Marks are awarded for amusement and lack of effort, and competitors are frequently disqualified for applying too much effort. In 2001, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' tabloid newspaper featured its own Turnip Prize.<ref>{{cite news |last=Spanton |first=Tim |date=2001 |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,5-2001390088_1,00.html |title=It's the Turnip Prize |newspaper=The Sun |accessdate=8 January 2007}}{{dead link |date=November 2018}}</ref>
In 2002 "The Turnip Award" was opened annually for students at [[Edinburgh College of Art]] to "carve or design something out of the humble vegetable".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tuco.org/news.asp?month=11&year=2004 |title=Edinburgh College of Art Turnip Prize |archivedate= 29 September 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929002900/http://www.tuco.org/news.asp?month=11&year=2004 |date=November 2004|accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref> The 2005 prize was a mountain bike.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment.cfm?|title=Artists turnip in their droves |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=28 October 2005 |archivedate=28 October 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604230030/http://news.scotsman.com/edinburgh/Artists-turnip-in-their-droves.2673358.jp |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref> In 2005 a Turnip Prize was staged at St Paul's Gallery in [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets|Tower Hamlets]], London, for local residents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.towerhamlets.gov.uk/templates/news/detail.cfm?newsid=6242 |title=Turnip heads the art world |work=East End Life |date=15 August 2006 |archivedate=21 August 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060821181553/https://www.towerhamlets.gov.uk/templates/news/detail.cfm?newsid=6242 |accessdate=7 November 2018}}</ref>
The term was previously used in 1998 by [[YBA]] Jake Chapman of the [[Chapman Brothers]] (2003 Turner Prize nominees): "We thought if we couldn't get the Turner Prize we should get the Turnip Prize."<ref>{{cite news |last=Barker |first=Godfrey |url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4153/is_19980708/ai_n11871702 |title=Back to school, and no virgins |newspaper=Evening Standard |date=8 July 1998 |accessdate=9 January 2007}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=February 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''William Saurin Lyster''' (21 March 1828 – 27 November 1880) was an [[impresario]], active in Australia.
== Early life == Lyster was born in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]], the third son of Chaworth Lyster, a captain in the army, and his wife Anne, ''née'' Keightly. His uncle was [[William Saurin]], [[Attorney-General for Ireland]]. The Saurin family was partly of French [[Hugenot]] extraction. Another of his uncles was [[James Saurin]], [[Bishop of Dromore]]. At the age of 13, Lyster, after an illness, was sent on a voyage round the world and visited [[Sydney]] and [[Melbourne]] in 1842. After his return to England he went to India, intending to become a planter, but, the climate not suiting him, he again returned to England. In 1847 he was in South Africa and fought in the [[Xhosa Wars|7th Cape Frontier War]], and a year later was in the United States where he tried his fortunes as an actor with little success.
== Impresario career == In 1855 Lyster was a member of [[William Walker (filibuster)|General Walker]]'s expedition to [[Nicaragua]] with the rank of captain. About two years later he formed an [[opera]] company which included Madame Lucy Escott, Henry Squires, and Miss Georgia Hodson whom he married. This company had some success in the western states of America, and in 1861 Lyster brought it to Australia. For about seven years it gave performances of the operas of Italian, German, French and English composers, including ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' in 1861, and the ''[[Les Huguenots]]'' in 1862. Other companies were brought out in later years, and at times [[comic opera]] was alternated with [[grand opera]]. His opera company gave 1,459 performances between 1861 and 1869.
Classic operas like ''[[Lohengrin (opera)|Lohengrin]]'', opened 18 August 1877, and ''[[Tannhäuser (opera)|Tannhäuser]]'' in 1878, were box office failures, although the company had included a distinguished singer, Antoinetta Link. Lyster, however, made the lighter operas bear the cost of others which were artistic successes only. Among other singers brought out by Lyster were Signor Pietro Paladini and Madame {{Interlanguage link multi|Fanny Simonsen|de}}, grandmother of [[Frances Alda]]. The Australian tenor, [[Armes Beaumont]] joined his company in 1870. Among concert artists introduced to Australia were pianists [[Arabella Goddard]] and Henry Ketten, and [[Jules Levy (musician)|Jules Levy]], a well-known English [[cornet]] player of the period. Lyster's companies toured the principal cities of Australia and New Zealand, but for the last seven years of his life he made the [[Tivoli Theatre, Melbourne]] his headquarters. Though most renowned for his productions of operas, he was interested also in the drama, and seasons were played at the opera house by the distinguished actress [[Adelaide Ristori|Madame Ristori]], and by good comedy companies.
== Death == Lyster fell into bad health about 1877 and never fully recovered. He died in Melbourne on 27 November 1880 and was survived by his wife, there were no children. Lyster was buried in the [[Anglican]] section of the [[Melbourne General Cemetery]].
==References== *{{Dictionary of Australian Biography|First=William|Last=Lyster|shortlink=0-dict-biogL.html#lyster1|accessdate=29 August 2016}} *{{Australian Dictionary of Biography|first=Sally|last=O'Neill|first2=Maureen Thérèse|last2=Radic|title=Lyster, William Saurin (1828–1880)|volume=5|year=1974|id2=lyster-william-saurin-4053|accessdate=23 August 2016}}
==External links== *[http://www.liveperformance.com.au/halloffame/williamlyster1.html "William Saurin Lyster 1828–1880"], extensive biography, Live Performance Australia – Hall of Fame

{{short description|Traditional Chinese drum}} {{Multiple issues|{{more citations needed|date=November 2018}}{{copy edit|date=November 2018}}}}
The '''Yaogu''' is a traditional instrument in China. it is known as the symbolic of Chinese musical drums. It has unique performing forms as well as traditional customs, and it contributes to Chinese culture since it was created.
== Basic Introduction of the Yaogu ==
The Yaogu is a traditional instrument in China. In Chinese, the word “yao” means the waist of a human and “gu” refers to the drum. Different from other [[percussion instrument]]s, especially other [[drum]]s, the Yaogu is not only played using hands and arms, but is played using the whole body, driven by specific dance movements. Just as its name implies, the Yaogu is a type of Chinese musical drum, which is played on people’s waists, using hands or by holding two wood-made sticks.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The silk road encyclopedia|last=Su-Il,|first=Jeong|date=2016|publisher=Seoul Selection|isbn=978-1624120763|edition= English|location=Irvine, CA|oclc=955004028}}</ref> The Yaogu is tied by a piece of long red silk ribbon which wraps around one side of the shoulders and waist. It is in the shape of a short cylinder and it looks like a hourglass, and the ends of the two sides are slightly smaller than the middle section. In general, the drum is approximately 34 cm in length.
== History of the Yaogu ==
According to relevant data records, in ancient times, in the Yellow River valley, the male in every tribe used the sheepskins to wrap around the trunk of a tree and carried around the waist, in order to threaten the beasts and drive them away from the tribes.<ref>{{Citation|title=Xi bu zhi lian.|date=2008|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/771858552|others=Yang, Shulin., Lu, Yuan.|publisher=Guangzhou Shi xin shi dai|isbn=9787885256180|oclc=771858552|access-date=2018-10-30}}</ref>
The first percussion instrument originated four thousand years ago in China. It was in Shang Dynasty, which was defined by a neolithic time. During this period, percussion instruments including drums were widely used in celebration of Dynasty and the conflicts between vibes.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/671710042|title=Chinese music|last=scholar)|first=Jin, Jie (Music|date=2011|publisher=Cambridge University Press|others=Wang, Li., Li, Rong.|isbn=9780521186919|edition= Updated |location=Cambridge|oclc=671710042}}</ref> Drums are the symbol of spirit and power, represent the universe, which are the materials to show authority.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/895731298|title=Asian American religious cultures|others=Lee, Jonathan H. X.,, Matsuoka, Fumitaka,, Yee, Edmond, 1938-, Nakasone, Ronald Y.,|isbn=9781598843309|location=Santa Barbara|oclc=895731298}}</ref>
The most well-known waist drum around world is the culture of the Ansai Yaogu in northern Shanxi province, northwest China. Ansai is known as "the hometown of drums". The historical reason for the origin of the name of "Ansai' in Chinese is its meaning of the ambition to settle the frontier and remain stable and safe. Therefore, the Ansai Yaogu is an auspicious sign to Shanxi citizens.
Dating back to [[Qing dynasty|'''Qing''']] and [[Han dynasty|'''Han''']] Dynasties, the Yaogu was a significant tool to send signals for frontier guards, in order to inform their leaders that the foreign enemies were approaching towards the edge of territory.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sports Engineering and Computer Science : proceedings of the 2014 International Conference on Sport Science and Computer Science (SSCS 2014), Singapore, 16-17 September 2014 & the 2014 International Conference on Biomechanics and Sports Engineering (BSE 2014), Riga, Latvia, 24-25 October, 2014|others=Luo, Qi,, International Conference on Sport Science and Computer Science (2014 : Singapore), International Conference on Biomechanics and Sports Engineering (2014 : Riga, Latvia)|isbn=9781315755717|location=Boca Raton, FL|oclc=910237206|last1 = Luo|first1 = Qi|date=2015-05-27}}</ref> If the leaders heard the sound of the Yaogu from the frontier, it was the time to prepare weapons for the coming battle. Moreover, once the war began and two armies fought against each other, the Yaogu played the role of encouraging soldiers to keep up high morale. Besides the warning and encouraging roles, the Yaogu was also played to celebrate the victory when soldiers won the war. With the passage of time, the Yaogu became a type of instrument with the folk customs and popularity among plain citizens. People played the Yaogu if there was a great harvest of crops and festival celebration.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=dZpDAQAAIAAJ&q=Harvest+and+waist+drums+in+china&dq=Harvest+and+waist+drums+in+china&hl=zh-CN&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ_JH90K3eAhVGyLwKHduMCWAQ6AEILzAB|title=Survey of China Mainland Press|date=September 1971|publisher=American Consulate General|language=en}}</ref> It is believed that the sound of the Yaogu brings luck to local areas when they were praying. [[File:Binus Operet 24-10-2009 Yangge.JPG|thumb|287x287px|Yangko (Yangge): Traditional Chinese dance performance]] At the beginning of 20 century, the yaogu was combined with dance when the peasants were working in the fields. For the original motivation, in order to recover from fatigue as well as boredom, peasants in northwest of China developed a dance named "Yangko" from the fieldwork. Yangko, named '''[[Yangge]]''' as well, is a popular rural folk dance today.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mao's cultural army : drama troupes in China's rural revolution|last=James,|first=DeMare, Brian|isbn=9781107076327|location=Cambridge|oclc=897510462|date = 2015-04-02}}</ref> Back then, the peasants noticed that they were just simply dancing without sounds, thus, they played the Yaogu together with Yangko. This mode of dancing and the combination of the Yaogu was made for entertaining the peasants and praying for the harvest of crops.
== Contemporary Development of the Yaogu ==
* The Yaogu and its dance become increasingly popular within northwest China. The Ansai Yaogu has won a large amount of national and international prizes from 1986. It contributed to the performances on the opening ceremony of the 11th Asian Sports Games, Hongkong handover celebration, 2009 National Day ceremony and other large-scale activities. In the meantime, the Yaogu performs worldwide and goes global. It successively performed in other countries such as Japan and Germany. * As the consequence of the social significance of the Yaogu in local areas, some children who have passion on the Yaogu learned the way of performing it in their young ages. Nowadays, it is said by Jijiang Feng, the deputy mayor of Yan'an City that there are more than 40,000 out of 160,000 citizens are able to play the Yaogu in the town of Ansai. The Yaogu education has been considered to be compulsory in many Shanxi families. * Furthermore, as working pressure rises, the Yaogu has become a bodybuilding exercise in part of China. They have to sit in front of their computer and stay in the office for a whole day. As a result, a large number of office workers have the problem of a backache. Therefore, the bodybuilding exercise is designed easily for the office worker for them to release the stress as well as to alleviate the symptoms.
== Traditional Customs of the Yaogu == The Yaogu is widely used in Chinese traditional sacrificial ceremony. Especially peasants pray to the gods for protection and rains. Once it is approaching to Autumn, the local percussion team usually start to prepare for the event of blessing a good harvest. Two head leaders guide the whole team towards the blessing destination, dancing with the dance movements and the roll of drums. Identically, when the new year begins, the Yaogu teams contribute their performance to pray for world peace and prosperity. In local traditions in, the family hosts in Shanxi believe that the drumbeats given out by the team emblems the elimination of disasters and unfortunates. If two Yaogu team meets on the road, the thing happens more often is that two teams will intend to start a battle. The battle is made up of singing in antiphonal style part and playing drumbeats in improvisation. The way to determine a win or a loss of this battle is to look at who is the first one to stop singing or whose drum team is in disarray. The team which lose the battle will show their respect and leave the road for the winner. The existence of battle aims to raise the culmination of their performing atmosphere by competing skills, which reflects the sprits of competition for Shanxi people.
== Yaogu Dance Movements== <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1043052885|title=Revolutionary bodies : Chinese dance and the socialist legacy|last=1981-|first=Wilcox, Emily,|isbn=9780520971905|location=Oakland, California|oclc=1043052885}}</ref>
* Yaogu performers are usually required to be full of energy when then are dancing. They move their bodies naturally with the beats of drums and musical rhythm to express passions. Performers shook their heads slightly and waved their shoulders strongly in order to combine Yaogu dancing movements with personal emotions, under the rendering of music. They need to make appropriate expressions and body movements with the drum beats.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.visiontimes.com/2016/07/01/the-joy-of-the-chinese-waist-drum-dance.html|title=The Joy of the Chinese Waist Drum Dance - Vision Times|website=www.visiontimes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> * As for the power and sound of the drums, performers are taught to hit the drumheads on two sides and the middle part of the Yaogu with great force when appropriate as they made different sounds. The sound of drum head is strong and deep, which expresses strength and power; on the contrary, the sound of drumbody is clear and crisp, which expresses soft and delicacy. Therefore, the Yaogu dance requires performers to be capable of rigorous control of the force, so as to achieve the combination of music, dance and human. * For body movements, dancers move according to the rhythm of drumbeats and other instrument. Dancers jump, kick, twist, squat down and stand up. The requirement for dancers is that all the turns in Yaogu dance have to be strong, in order to connect with next movement compactly without stop and hesitation. * The most famous movement of the Yaogu performance is called "drumming turn". As its name implies, performers need to complete the drumming and dance performance at the same time. Drums are on waists tightly, next, dancers jump as high as they can to make turns in the air. * * The movements of the waist drum are tight and strong, so the performers need to arm with sufficient physical strength and energy to complete the drumming and dancing in the meantime.
== Performing Forms == There are two main types of performing strategies of the Yaogu: one is "Wengu", which means that the performers twist theirselves heavily and hit lightly; on the contrary, another one is "Wugu", performers hit heavily and twist lightly. "Wengu" trends to show the vivacity of the Yaogu and it is similar to "'''Yangko'''". Inversely, "Wugu" focus on power and the integration with Chinese acrobatic fighting movements, which preaches passion. The Yaogu has organically formed a mixture of waist drum, dance, percussion music, folk song and Wushu (martial arts in China, such as shadow-boxing, swordplay etc.). The combination of Chinese traditional features impels the influence of the Yaogu to spread it culture worldwide.
In adddition, the Yaogu has two performing forms including "Lugu (road drum)" and "Changdigu (court drum)". "Lugu" is a form that a long team of players walk and do the hitting in the street. The team has two head leaders in the front to navigate the passing road, following a major director who controls the rhythm and speed of the whole group and make sure the quality of this show. Performers ususally have their own characters to set the personal dance movement and the Yaogu actions. For "Court Drum", it refers to a form that performance begins in a specific place. To begin with, two head leaders give out "starting" commands when they are ready. Dancers move with the Yaogu, and the movements are aiming to warm up the court in order to attract audience's attention. Moving to the second part, folk music and percussion actions are to connect while others dancing and singing beside the group. This part is large-scale for that performers are doing more complex steps than that in first part before. Once the sound of the Yaogu and music stops, participants will call out words of blessing for health, family and crops. After that, the Yaogu activity moves to the final part, which is the most challenging section for the performers. They have to do as many as they can to show the charm of waist drum and their individual talent. It is the most difficult but would reaches the climax of the whole show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://big5.xinhuanet.com/gate/big5/www.godpp.gov.cn/wmzh/2007-07/11/content_10545381.htm|title=安塞腰鼓|website=big5.xinhuanet.com|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref>
Moreover, the Yaogu can also play a leading part in a performance by standing in front of an orchestra.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chime : newsletter of the European Foundation for Chinese Music Research|last=|first=|publisher=European Foundation for Chinese Music Research|year=1990|location=Shanghai|pages=43}}</ref>
[[File:Waist drums in Ansai.jpg|thumb|Waist drums in Ansai, Shanxi, China|304x304px]]
As its performance indicates, the Yaogu has a strong artistic shock with its unique style, moving charm, colourful movements and strong image. It is said that the Yaogu makes people feel passionate and looks refreshed. The artistic image of "beauty" and "power" reflected by it fully reproduces the spirit of the times and the image of the nation, and is an indispensable part of the culture of the Yellow River Basin.
Generally, the Yaogu not only can be performed by less than ten people, but also sometimes played by a large number of hundreds of people. Waist drum pays attention to collective, grand and magnificent momentum. Individuals in the Yaogu team has their own characters during the performance.
== Cultural value and significance of the Yaogu == The Yaogu opened a channel for traditional Chinese percussion instruments.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/955004028|title=The silk road encyclopedia|last=Su-Il,|first=Jeong|date=2016|publisher=Seoul Selection|isbn=1624120768|edition= English |location=Irvine, CA|oclc=955004028}}</ref> For a long time ago, the Yaogu has been integrated into Shaanxi local culture and Chinese national culture and it has become the benchmark and symbol in the history of Chinese music culture.
From the personal and local aspects, the Yaogu illustrates the simple and unconstrained character of the farmers in the northwest loess plateau and the unique artistic personality. Furthermore, its performance form expresses the collective spirit of the Shanxi people and good wishes for life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.visiontimes.com/2016/07/01/the-joy-of-the-chinese-waist-drum-dance.html|title=The Joy of the Chinese Waist Drum Dance - Vision Times|website=www.visiontimes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>
From the social aspects, the value of the Yaogu is reflected in the fact that it represents Shaanxi Province and even China to play a significant role in propaganda on the world cultural stage. As its highly spiritual status, on May 20 in 2006, the Ansai Yaogu was approved by the state council to be included in the first batch of national intangible cultural heritage list.
